{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Criticism of religion sidebar}} [[Sikhism]] has been criticized in one way or another by proponents of other theories. These critics include both Sikhs and non-Sikhs under different motives. These criticisms extend across a large portion of the beliefs and practices of Sikhism and even question the authenticity of the origin of the faith. As a result, Sikhs continue to face discrimination due to their presence and past activities.
==Theology== Scholar [[W H McLeod|William Hewat McLeod]] cited the tension between the doctrine of God's [[Transcendence (religion)#Sikhism|transcendence]] in Sikhism and a supposed ability of God to communicate with people. McLeod says Sikh thinkers have been unable to give a convincing account of how God can communicate with people at all if this being is indeed transcendent.<ref>Mandair, A.-P. S., ''Religion and the Specter of the West'' ([[Columbia University Press]], 2009), p. 261.</ref> Although, this is what makes Sikh teachings different from other schools of thought i.e., that God is transcendental, formless and infinite but still can communicate to people as if a physical being.
Hindu leader [[Dayanand Saraswati]], in his book ''[[Satyarth Prakash]]'', criticized [[Sikhism]], describing [[Guru Nanak]] as a "rogue",<ref>"Reduced to Ashes: The Insurgency and Human Rights in Punjab ..., Volume 1", p.16</ref> the hymns of the [[Guru Granth Sahib]] as falsehood, and Sikhism as a snare to rob and cheat simple folk of their wealth and property. A Sikh wrote a response, to which Dayanand Saraswati answered that his opinion had undergone a change when he visited [[Punjab]], and the remarks about Sikhism would be deleted in the subsequent edition of his work. However, these remarks were never removed after the untimely death of Dayanand Saraswati, and later editions of ''Satyarth Prakash'' were even more critical of Sikhism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sikhinstitute.org/jan_2007/3-gansi.htm|title=Institute of Sikh Studies, Chandigarh|publisher=|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
===Religious text=== [[File:Guru Granth Sahib Sikh scripture with Chauri on the left.jpg|thumb|Guru Granth Sahib being read.]] [[Ernest Trumpp]] had concluded that [[Guru Granth Sahib|Adi Granth]] was not worth translating in full--"the same few ideas, he thought, being endlessly repeated," and referring to the heterogeneous language (mostly Sadhukkadi or Saint's tongue, a mixture of Indian dialects, used by saints to preach in North India)<ref>{{Cite book|title=Guru Granth Sahib|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=esp. Kabir, Ravidas and most of Nanak's Shlokas}}</ref> that consisted of various dialects, he described the text as "incoherent and shallow in the extreme, and couched at the same time in dark and perplexing language, in order to cover these defects. It is for us Occidentals a most painful and almost stupefying task, to read only a single Rag."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Tony Ballantyne|title=Between Colonialism and Diaspora: Sikh Cultural Formations in an Imperial World|date=26 Jul 2006|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=9780822388111|pages=52–3}}<!--|accessdate=1 September 2014--></ref> Even for Sikhs the language of the Guru Granth Sahib is considered archaic and hard to understand without an interpreter.<ref>{{cite book|author1=S. K. Rait|title=Sikh Women in England: Their Religious and Cultural Beliefs and Social Practices|date=2005|publisher=Trentham Books|isbn=9781858563534|page=39|edition=illustrated}}</ref> Trumpp viewed Adi Granth to be lacking theological transcendence and lacking systematic unity.<ref>"Sikhism: A Guide for the Perplexed", by Arvind-Pal Singh Mandair, p. 87</ref> He also stated that the injunctions of the Rehit-nama, authored by Prahlad Singh (a close associate of [[Guru Gobind Singh]]), regarding Sikh relations with Muslims, showed "a narrow-minded bigotry and a deep fanatical hatred."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Tony Ballantyne|title=Between Colonialism and Diaspora: Sikh Cultural Formations in an Imperial World|date=26 Jul 2006|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=9780822388111|page=53}}<!--|accessdate=1 September 2014--></ref>
Regarding the [[Dasam Granth]], the second scripture of Sikhs written by the 10th [[Guru Gobind Singh]], there is much controversy among Sikh scholars regarding its authorship.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Robin Rinehart|title=Debating the Dasam Granth|date=5 Jan 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199842476|page=8}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Pashaura Singh|author2=Louis E. Fenech|title=The Oxford Handbook of Sikh Studies|date=18 Mar 2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780191004124|page=146}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref> There are also references in the text to multiple gods such as [[Brahma]], [[Vishnu]], [[Shiva]], [[Govind (disambiguation)|Govind]] and [[Chandi]], included in such compositions as the [[Chandi di Var]] of the 5th chapter of the text.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dev|first=Nanak|authorlink=Guru Nanak Dev Ji|title=Gurū Granth Sāhib Ji|url=http://www.srigranth.org/servlet/gurbani.gurbani?Action=Page&Param=1036&punjabi=t#l44327|accessdate=15 June 2006|page=1036|quote=When He so willed, He created the world. Without any supporting power, He sustained the universe. He created Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva; He fostered enticement and attachment to Maya.}}</ref> This has led to the text being described as having "fluid boundaries between polytheism and monotheism."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Pashaura Singh|author2=Norman Gerald Barrier|title=The transmission of Sikh heritage in the diaspora|date=1 Jul 1996|publisher=Manohar Publishers & Distributors|isbn=9788173041556|page=60}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Robin Rinehart|title=Debating the Dasam Granth|date=5 Jan 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199842476|pages=8, 70}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref> Some Sikhs also believe the text promotes sexual promiscuity (including multiple references to group sex), degrades women and also encourages use of intoxicants.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Raveena Aulakh|title=Did Guru Gobind Singh write the Dasam Granth?|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/insight/2010/04/11/did_guru_gobind_singh_write_the_dasam_granth.html|website=thestar.com|publisher=Toronto Star Newspapers|accessdate=13 September 2014|date=Apr 11, 2010}}</ref>
===Monotheism=== Sikhism defines the concept of one God as [[Ik Onkar|Ek Onkar]].<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/gcsebitesize/rs/god/sikhismrev2.shtml</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Sikhs in Europe: Migration, Identities and Representations|page=101|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y3v3t9bjPAcC&pg=PA192&dq=sikhism+gurus+onkar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=D3NXUu3LOMXUrQe6pICQBA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=sikhism%20gurus%20onkar&f=false}}</ref> While the concept of [[monotheism]] was already taught in the [[Vedas]],<ref>"Divine Message Of God To Mankind Vedas" by J.M. Mehta, Chapter '12. Worship of God'.</ref> other later scriptures such as [[Bhagavad Gita]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Zaehner|first=Robert Charles|title=The Bhagavad-Gita|page=141|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nY6PRhqdlJsC&pg=PA141}}</ref> [[Torah]],<ref>"Modern Scholarship in the Study of Torah", p.165, by Shalom Carmy</ref> [[Quran]],<ref>"One God in One Man" By C. T. Benedict, page.179</ref> that came about long before the religion of Sikhism. However, it has been suggested that Sikhism's monotheism differs from other religions.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kelemen|first=Lawrence Charles|title=Permission to Receive: Four Rational Approaches to the Torah's Divine Origin|page=27|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YOHpUbHCY_cC&pg=PA27}}</ref> According to [[Ernest Trumpp]], the Sikh [[God in Sikhism|theology of God]] is "far closer in conception to the [[pantheistic]] traditions of Hinduism than the monotheistic perspective of Christianity."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Pashaura Singh|author2=Louis E. Fenech|title=The Oxford Handbook of Sikh Studies|date=18 Mar 2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780191004124|page=74}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref>
Guru Nanak opposed [[polytheistic]] practices. According to a legend, Nanak during his trip to [[Mecca]] had debate with [[mullahs]] of Mecca, in his debate, Nanak had asserted that the [[Kaaba]] was only a black stone, which is [[Lingam]], of Lord [[Shiva]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Needham Cust|first=Robert|title=Linguistic and Oriental Essays|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t_AIAAAAQAAJ}}</ref> However it has been alleged that later gurus of Sikhism added the practices that can be linked with polytheism,<ref>{{cite book|last=Pruthi|first=Raj|title=Sikhism and Indian Civilization|page=16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KxndvJs3wUkC&pg=PA16}}</ref> most notably waving fans over Guru Granth Sahib during worship.<ref>"The Guru Granth Sahib and Sikhism", p. 28, by Anita Ganeri</ref><ref>"Hindu Religion: Customs and Manners; Describing the Customs and Manners, Religious, Social and Domestic Life, Arts and Sciences of the Hindus", p. 78, by Paul Thomas</ref> Sikhism also permits the veneration and [[Intercession of saints]] (such as to the Sikh martyr [http://www.sikhiwiki.org/index.php/Bhai_Maharaj_Singh%20Bhai Bhai Maharaj Singh]) and views its Gurus as the "embodiment of Divine Light" and "Divine in Spirit",<ref>{{cite web|title=Concept of Guru|url=http://searchsikhism.com/concept-of-guru|website=Search Sikhism|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref> which are seen by some religious groups as forms of polytheism.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Rajesh Rai|author2=Peter Reeves|title=The South Asian Diaspora: Transnational Networks and Changing Identities|date=25 Jul 2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134105953|page=188}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Kelly Pemberton|author2=Michael Nijhawan|title=Shared Idioms, Sacred Symbols, and the Articulation of Identities in South Asia|date=25 Oct 2011|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135904777|pages=143, 161}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref>
===Syncretism=== {{see also|Islam and Sikhism|Hinduism and Sikhism}}
One view of Sikhism is that it is a [[syncretism]] of Hinduism (particularly the [[Bhakti]] movement) and Islam (particularly [[Sufism]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Propositional Religions 5 - Sikhism|url=http://www.biblestudying.net/mysticism5.html|accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|title=Flawed Definitions of Sikhism|url=http://www.sikhcoalition.org/flawed-definitions-of-sikhism|website=THE SIKH COALITION|accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=A History of the Sikhs|last=Singh|first=Khushwant|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>), having evolved from Hinduism in the context of a multiplicity of syncretic movements in [[Medieval India]], while taking the idea of monotheism from Islam,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Roger Griffin|authorlink1=Roger Griffin|title=Terrorist's Creed: Fanatical Violence and the Human Need for Meaning|date=2012|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781137284723|edition=illustrated|quote=By hybridizing Hinduism - particularly elements of Vaishnavism with its stress on active devotion ('bhakti') - with Islam - especially its monotheism and Sufi mystic tradition - a new monotheistic religion was born...}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Shashi Tharoor|title=[[India: From Midnight to the Millennium]]|date=2006|publisher=Arcade Publishing|isbn=9781559708036|page=368|edition=reprint, revised}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=John McCannon|title=AP World History, 6th ed.|date=2014|publisher=Barron's Educational Series|isbn=9781438092669|quote=While many consider Sikhism to have emerged as an independent tradition, it is categorized by others as a syncretic faith, joining certain aspects of Hindu theology with the monotheism associated with Islam.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Holm|editor1-first=Jean|editor2-last=Bowker|editor2-first=John|title=Picturing God|date=1994|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=9781441120311|page=192}}</ref> as well as the incorporation of selected hymns from Hindu and Muslim saints (such as [[Kabir]], [[Fariduddin Ganjshakar]] and other [[Bhagat]]) into the [[Guru Granth Sahib]].<ref name="auto"/> This view was commonly believed, but is outdated within scholarship.<ref>Dhanjal, B., "Sikhism" in Holm & Bowker (eds.), ''Picturing God'' ([[Continuum International Publishing Group|Continuum]], 1994), p. 192.</ref>
According to [[Harjot Oberoi]], until the 19th century the Sikhs had shown "little collective interest in distinguishing themselves from the Hindus" and "Sikh notions of time, space, corporality, holiness, kinship, social distinctions, purity and pollution and commensality were hardly different from those of the Hindus."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Girja Kumar|title=The Book on Trial: Fundamentalism and Censorship in India|date=1 Jan 1997|publisher=Har-Anand Publications|isbn=9788124105252|page=385}}<!--|accessdate=13 September 2014--></ref> The Sikh belief in [[Reincarnation]] is also often used as proof of the syncretic influence of Hinduism on Sikhism,<ref>{{cite web|title=Q: What happens after death?|url=http://www.realsikhism.com/index.php?subaction=showfull&id=1248308791&ucat=7|website=RealSikhism|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Douglas A. Phillips|author2=Charles F. Gritzner|title=India|date=1 Jan 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=9781438105109|page=67}}<!--|accessdate=14 September 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Joseph Grcic|title=Facing Reality: An Introduction to Philosophy Revised Edition|date=1 Oct 2009|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=9781449033026|page=230}}<!--|accessdate=14 September 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Norman C. McClelland|title=Encyclopedia of Reincarnation and Karma|date=1 Apr 2010|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786456758|page=248}}<!--|accessdate=14 September 2014--></ref> although that belief in reincarnation also existed in other [[Indian religions]], including [[Buddhism]] and [[Jainism]] before the conception of Sikhism.<ref>{{cite book|author=Tabassum Javeed, Ali Javid|title=World Heritage Monuments and Related Edifices in India, Volume 1|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=fg-lGID3WpQC&pg=PA8 |year=2008|publisher=Algora Publishing|isbn=9780875864839 |page=8}}</ref>
===Ban on hair removal=== The cutting or removal of hair from any body part (including nose hair, ear hair, facial hair and pubic hair)<ref>{{cite book|author1=Scott Lowe|title=Hair|date=2016|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing USA|isbn=9781628922219|page=93}}</ref> is strictly [[Prohibitions in Sikhism|forbidden for Sikhs]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Khushwant Singh|authorlink1=Khushwant Singh|title=[[Truth, Love & a Little Malice|Truth, Love and a Little Malice: An Autobiography]]|date=2003|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=9780143029571|page=369|edition=reprint, revised}}</ref> This growing of ones hair is known as [[Kesh (Sikhism)|Kesh]].<ref>{{cite news|author1=Lalita Clozel|title=U.S. Sikhs say military's ban on long hair and beards keeps them out|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2014/apr/13/nation/la-na-military-sikhs-20140414|accessdate=1 September 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|date=April 13, 2014|quote=The turban, hair and beard date from the 17th century, when the last living Sikh Guru, Gobind Singh, decided that followers should allow their hair to grow as a sign of respect for God, known as Kesh.}}</ref> However, the practice is a common source of criticism and questioning of Sikhism, including the belief that not cutting ones hair will cause it to grow to unacceptably long lengths.<ref>{{cite web|title=Q: Why do Sikhs keep hair?|url=http://www.realsikhism.com/index.php?subaction=showfull&id=1248364871&ucat=7|website=RealSikhism|accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> Non-[[Amrit Sanchar|amritdhari]] young women, especially, often express criticism of the forbiddance to cut hair as being too demanding and restrictive.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Gallo|editor1-first=Ester|title=Migration and Religion in Europe: Comparative Perspectives on South Asian Experiences|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317096375|page=104}}</ref>
===Ethnoreligious group=== Sikhism has been criticised for the perception that it is an [[ethnoreligious group]], which has seemingly very limited appeal and following beyond those claiming ancestry from the [[Indian subcontinent]] — especially the [[Punjab region]] and its surrounds, such as among the [[Jat Sikh]]<ref>{{cite book|author1=J. S. Grewal|title=The Sikhs of the Punjab|date=8 Oct 1998|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521637640|pages=138–9}}<!--|accessdate=7 September 2014--></ref>{{efn|Jat Sikhs have been described as "the backbone of the Sikh movement under the leadership of the Sikh Gurus."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Sewa Singh Kalsi|title=Sikhism|date=1 Jan 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=9781438106472|page=86}}<!--|accessdate=7 September 2014--></ref>}} and [[Khatri#Sikh Khatris|Sikh Khatris]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Pritam Singh|title=Federalism, Nationalism and Development: India and the Punjab Economy|date=19 Feb 2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134049462|page=21}}<!--|accessdate=7 September 2014--></ref> South Asia alone accounts for up to 90% of the total [[Sikhism by country|Sikh population]] and approximately 75% of all [[Sikh]]s live in [[Punjab, India]]. Sikhism does not actively [[proselytize]], and discourages it, perhaps explaining the homogeneous nature of the religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u37XAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=The Sovereignty of the Sikh Doctrine|publisher=|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
===Violence=== [[File:Sikh symbol.jpg|thumb|Khanda emblem of Sikhism]] {{main article|Sikhism and violence}} Similar to other religions, Sikhism (and its adherents) has been accused of violence, or the glorification thereof,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Michael S. Roth|author2=Charles G. Salas|title=Disturbing Remains: Memory, History, and Crisis in the Twentieth Century|date=2001|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=9780892365388|page=54}}<!--|accessdate=7 September 2014--></ref> through its history (such as the militarisation of the [[Khalsa]]),<ref>{{cite book|author1=Pashaura Singh|author2=Louis E. Fenech|title=The Oxford Handbook of Sikh Studies|date=2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199699308|page=31}}<!--|accessdate=7 September 2014--></ref> symbols (such as the [[Khanda (Sikh symbol)|Khanda]]),<ref>{{cite book|author1=Mark Juergensmeyer|title=Terror in the Mind of God: The Global Rise of Religious Violence|date=2003|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520240117|page=163}}<!--|accessdate=7 September 2014--></ref> art and legend.<ref>{{cite book|author1=David C. Rapoport|title=Inside Terrorist Organizations|date=5 Nov 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135311858|page=179}}<!--|accessdate=7 September 2014--></ref> However this has been rejected by [[David C. Rapoport]]: "It would be convenient to say that the prestige of violent symbols in the Sikh religion has increased Sikhs' propensity for violent action, or that the Sikh religion is violent because Sikhs as a people are violent, but i do not think either of these arguments can be made very convincingly."<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Rapoport|editor1-first=David C.|title=Inside Terrorist Organizations|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135311858|page=179}}</ref> Sikhs believe that violence is acceptable as a last resort<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=William|title=Moral Issues in Six Religions|date=1991|publisher=Heinemann|isbn=9780435302993|page=212}}</ref> and that weapons are sacred as they are seen as means to fight so called evil forces or tyrants.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Renard|first1=John|title=Fighting Words: Religion, Violence, and the Interpretation of Sacred Texts|date=2012|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520274198|page=211}}</ref>
The tenth Guru was an avid hunter, noting in his autobiography his success in killing antelope, elk, bears, and lions.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} He is often portrayed with his hunting hawk and hunting dogs, and regarded as a huntsman. Louis E. French conjectures that Guru Gobind Singh may have hunted, as was common among Mughal rulers, "to demonstrate his own physical and tactical prowess, to familiarize himself with the lay of the land, and to gather intelligence through networks of his own equivalent of the famous harkāre"<ref>{{cite book|author1=Louis E. Fenech|title=The Sikh Ẓafar-nāmah of Guru Gobind Singh: A Discursive Blade in the Heart of the Mughal Empire|date=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn= 9780199931439|page=13}}<!--|accessdate=29 July 2017--></ref>
==In academia== Sikh groups have put pressure on universities, and there has been a movement among some Sikhs to stifle academic criticism of Sikhism in North America.<ref>Hawley & Mann, "Introduction" in ''Studying the Sikhs'' ([[SUNY Press]], 1993), p. 3.</ref>
==Relations with other religions and communities== [[File:Jacques Chirac.jpg|thumb|right|125px|A ban on [[French law on secularity and conspicuous religious symbols in schools|religious symbols]] that included Sikh signs was introduced in France under the presidency of [[Jacques Chirac]].]] There is a history of tension between Sikhism and Islam. This goes back to the persecution of Sikhs by the [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] emperors in India, but has manifested in more recent distrust between the communities in the UK, including hostility to inter-community romantic relationships.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hundal|first=Sunny|title=Sikhs v Muslims: why the debate on grooming isn’t about the women themselves|url=http://liberalconspiracy.org/2013/09/12/sikhs-v-muslims-why-the-debate-on-grooming-isnt-about-the-women-themselves/|work=Liberal Conspiracy|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref>
Prior to the 1947 [[Partition of India]] promises of a Sikh majority state were outlined, however following the divide of India and the creation of Pakistan, renegation on such promises was the approach taken by the Indian government of the time. Following this, the actions occurring in [[Operation Blue Star]] which were seen as atrocities by Sikhs, led to worldwide protests and renewed demands for a separate nation as was previously promised, they called it "[[Khalistan movement]]", during this movement, some Sikhs had been involved in retaliatory-terrorism, the most well-known incident being [[Air India Flight 182]], in which 268 Canadian citizens died. Many of the Sikh groups were [[Khalistan movement#Khalistan militant outfits|banned]] from the numerous countries, who had been convicted with terrorist activities. Due to such negative impact, the support for [[Khalistan Movement]] has been commonly regarded as act of terrorism, many have been arrested for affirming support for the movement.<ref>"Congressional Record, V. 152, PT. 17, November 9, 2006 to December 6, 2006", p. 606</ref>
The present situation in Punjab is usually regarded as a cautionary tension with elements of peace; and the militant movement (Khalistan) has been weakened.
In 2004, [[France]] had passed the [[French law on secularity and conspicuous religious symbols in schools|law on secularity and conspicuous religious symbols in schools]], which banned many religious signs in schools. This ban most notably included [[Dastar|turbans]], a religious garment and central characteristic of Sikh religious code and practice.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-16547479|title=UN human rights body backs French Sikhs on turbans|work=BBC News|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> Since the number of Sikhs in France is a small minority, the French education minister claimed ignorance of the consequences such an act would have for the Sikh population residing in France. This law led to Sikhs protesting against the law across [[Europe]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3448239.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Europe - Sikhs protest against French ban|publisher=|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> [[India]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-02-16/india/37132455_1_french-turban-ban-sikh-children-ban-on-religious-symbols|title=India News, Latest Sports, Bollywood, World, Business & Politics News - Times of India|work=The Times of India|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> as well as other regions. This issue is heatedly debated as exploitation of secularism appears to infringe on the universal right and principal - freedom of expression. [[European Court of Human Rights]] dismissed the petition. Although [[United Nations|UN]]'s human right body supported the petition in January 2012, citing that turbans do not pose a threat to ground security.
In [[Canada]], a 2013 poll concluded that 39% of Canadians had a negative view of Sikhism, second after [[Islam]], which was negatively viewed by 54%.<ref>[http://www.angusreidglobal.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/Canadians-view-non-Christian-religions-with-uncertainty-dislike.pdf Canadian Public Opinion Poll], 2 October 2013</ref>

{{Criticism of religion sidebar}} {{Zoroastrianism}} {{Lead too short|date=September 2016}} '''Criticism of [[Zoroastrianism]]''' has taken place over many centuries not only from the adherents of other religions but also among Zoroastrians themselves seeking to reform the faith.
==Zoroaster== In the early 19th century, a Christian missionary based in [[British India]], [[John Wilson (missionary)|John Wilson]], claimed that [[Zoroaster]] never had a genuine divine commission (or ever claimed such a role),<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Sharma|editor1-first=Suresh K.|editor2-last=Sharma|editor2-first=Usha|title=Cultural and Religious Heritage of India: Zoroastrianism|date=2004|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=9788170999621|pages=17–18}}</ref> never performed miracles, or uttered prophecies and that the story of his life is "a mere tissue of comparatively modern fables and fiction."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|pages=206–7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Stausberg|editor1-first=Michael|editor2-last=Vevaina|editor2-first=Yuhan Sohrab-Dinshaw|title=The Wiley-Blackwell Companion to Zoroastrianism|date=23 Mar 2015|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118785508|page=75}}</ref> Others assert that all the available Zoroastrian sources regarding Zoroaster only provide conflicting images about him,<ref>{{cite book|author1=S. Nigosian|title=Zoroastrian Faith: Tradition and Modern Research|date=24 Sep 1993|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=9780773564381|page=10}}</ref> especially between earlier and later sources.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Sharma|editor1-first=Suresh K.|editor2-last=Sharma|editor2-first=Usha|title=Cultural and Religious Heritage of India: Zoroastrianism|date=2004|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=9788170999621|page=14}}</ref>
==Literature== The [[Dasatir-i-Asmani]], while being accepted by Zoroastrian communities in Iran and India as genuine, especially by the [[Kadmi]], it is generally believed to be a forgery.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|page=204}}</ref>
Wilson argued that the [[Avesta]] could not be divinely inspired because much of its text was irrevocably lost or unintelligible<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|pages=205–6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Kenneth Boa|title=Cults, World Religions and the Occult|date=1990|publisher=David C Cook|isbn=9780896938236|page=48|edition=revised}}</ref> and [[Martin Haug]], who greatly helped the Parsis of India to defend their religion against the attacks of such Christian missionaries as Wilson, considered the [[Gathas]] to be the only texts and only authoritative scriptures that could be attributed to Zoroaster.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|pages=207–8}}</ref>
==Polytheism== John Wilson attacked the Zoroastrian reverence of the [[Amesha Spenta]] and [[Yazata]]s as a form of [[polytheism]], although the Parsis at the time immediately refuted this allegation and insisted that he had in fact addressed the ''Bundahishn'', a text whose relevance to their practice was remote.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|page=205}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Stausberg|editor1-first=Michael|title=Zoroastrian Rituals in Context|date=2004|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004131316|pages=479–80|edition=illustrated}}</ref> Critics also commonly claim that Zoroastrians are worshipers of other deities and elements of nature, such as [[Fire worship|of fire]]—with one prayer, the Litany to the fire (Atesh Niyaesh),<ref>{{cite book|author1=John R. Hinnells|title=The Zoroastrian Diaspora: Religion and Migration|date=28 Apr 2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198267591|page=706|edition=illustrated}}</ref> stating: "I invite, I perform (the worship) of you, the Fire, O son of Ahura Mazdā together with all fires"—and [[Mithra]].<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Stausberg|editor1-first=Michael|title=Zoroastrian Rituals in Context|date=2004|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004131316|pages=50, 298–99|edition=illustrated}}</ref> Some critics have charged Zoroastrians with being followers of [[Dualistic cosmology|dualism]], who only claimed to be followers of [[monotheism]] in modern times to confront the powerful influence of Christian and Western thought which "hailed monotheism as the highest category of theology."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Maneckji Nusservanji Dhalla|authorlink1=Maneckji Nusserwanji Dhalla|title=Zoroastrian Theology: From the Earliest Times to the Present Day|date=1914|page=337|url=http://www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/Zoroastrian_Theology_from_the_Earliest_Times_to_the_Present_Day_1000035071/369}}</ref> Critics insist that the monotheistic reformist view is seen to contradict the conservative (or traditional) view of a dualistic worldview most evident in the relationship between [[Ahura Mazda]] and [[Angra Mainyu]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=S. Nigosian|title=Zoroastrian Faith: Tradition and Modern Research|date=24 Sep 1993|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=9780773564381|page=116}}</ref> and arguing that Zoroastrians follow a belief system influenced by [[Henotheism#Zoroastrianism|henotheism]]. Other Western scholars such as [[Martin Haug]], however, have dismissed the concept of theological dualism as a corruption of Zoroaster's original teachings, gradually added by later adherents of the faith.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|pages=207–208}}</ref> Critics add that the fact that such differing views have proliferated are a sign of the enigmatic nature of the Zoroastrian beliefs regarding the divinity.<ref>{{cite book|author1=S. Nigosian|title=Zoroastrian Faith: Tradition and Modern Research|date=24 Sep 1993|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=9780773564381|page=23}}</ref>
==Inter-Zoroastrian divisions== Zoroastrian reformers, such as [[Maneckji Nusserwanji Dhalla]], have argued that literary precedence should be given to the Gathas, as a source of authority and textual authenticity. They have also deplored and criticized many Zoroastrian rituals (e.g. excessive ceremonialism and focus on purity,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Kenneth Boa|title=Cults, World Religions and the Occult|date=1990|publisher=David C Cook|isbn=9780896938236|page=48|edition=revised}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Stausberg|editor1-first=Michael|title=Zoroastrian Rituals in Context|date=2004|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004131316|page=43|edition=illustrated}}</ref> using "[[bull]]'s urine for ritual cleansing, the attendance of a dog to gaze at the corpse during funerary rites, the exposure of corpses [[Tower of Silence|on towers]] [for consumption by vultures and ravens]")<ref>{{cite book|author1=S. Nigosian|title=Zoroastrian Faith: Tradition and Modern Research|date=24 Sep 1993|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=9780773564381|page=116}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Stausberg|editor1-first=Michael|title=Zoroastrian Rituals in Context|date=2004|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004131316|page=471|edition=illustrated}}</ref> and theological and cosmological doctrines as not befitting of the faith.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|page=208}}</ref> This ''orthodox'' versus ''reformist'' controversy rages even on the internet.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Stausberg|editor1-first=Michael|title=Zoroastrian Rituals in Context|date=2004|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004131316|page=51|edition=illustrated}}</ref>
Divisions and tensions also exist between [[Zoroastrians in Iran|Iranian]] and [[Zoroastrianism in India|Indian Zoroastrians]] and over such issues as the authority of a [[Priestly caste|hereditary priesthood]] in the transmission and interpretation of the faith, ethnicity and the nature of [[Ahura Mazda]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|pages=221–2}}</ref> Historically, differences also existed between the Zoroastrian branches of [[Zurvanism]], [[Mazdakism]] and [[Mazdaism]].<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Leaman|editor1-first=Oliver|title=Encyclopedia of Asian Philosophy|date=19 Oct 2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134691159|page=608}}</ref>
==Who is a Zoroastrian (Zarathushti)?== Much like the question of [[who is a Jew?]], Zoroastrian identity, especially whether it is adopted through birth or belief (or both), "remains a cause for tension" within the community.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jenny Rose|title=Zoroastrianism: An Introduction|date=2 Apr 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857719713|pages=210–11, 220}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Ariane Sherine|title=Zoroastrianism needs to adapt its archaic laws – or die|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2013/dec/08/zorastrianism-adapt-archaic-laws-die-parsi|accessdate=22 June 2015|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|date=9 December 2013}}</ref> Reformers have criticised the orthodox refusal to accept religious converts as one reason for the communities' declining population.<ref>{{cite news|author1=LAURIE GOODSTEIN|title=Zoroastrians Keep the Faith, and Keep Dwindling|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/06/us/06faith.html?ref=us&_r=0|accessdate=26 July 2015|work=The New York Times|date=6 September 2006}}</ref>
==Predestination== Zoroastrians have been criticized by Muslim authors for their rejection of [[predestination]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=[[Ibn Taymiyyah]]|editor1-last=Memon|editor1-first=Muhammad Umar|editor1-link=Muhammad Umar Memon|title=Ibn Taimiya's Struggle Against Popular Religion: With an Annotated Translation of His Kitab iqtida as-sirat al-mustaqim mukhalafat ashab al-jahim|date=1976|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=9783111662381|page=117|edition=reprint}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Tamim Ansary|title=Destiny Disrupted: A History of the World Through Islamic Eyes|date=2010|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=9781586488130|page=9|edition=illustrated, reprint}}</ref> This follows a famous [[hadith]] of [[Muhammad]] in which he negatively associates the [[Qadariyah]] Islamic sect with the [[Magi]]ans.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Richard C. Martin|author2=Mark R. Woodward|author3=Dwi S. Atmaja|editor1-last=Atmaja|editor1-first=Dwi S.|title=Defenders of Reason in Islam: Mu'tazilism from Medieval School to Modern Symbol|date=1997|publisher=Oneworld Publications|isbn=9781851681471|page=86|edition=illustrated}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Muhammad Qasim Zaman|title=Religion and Politics Under the Early ʻAbbāsids: The Emergence of the Proto-Sunnī Elite|date=1997|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004106789|page=62}}</ref>
==Patriarchy== Zoroastrianism has been criticized for the perception that it promotes a [[patriarchal system]], expressed through such avenues as an all-male priesthood and its historical allowance of [[polygamy]]—practiced by Zoroaster himself.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ghada Hashem Talhami|title=Historical Dictionary of Women in the Middle East and North Africa|date=2013|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780810868588|pages=186, 372}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Dale T. Irvin|author2=Scott Sunquist|title=History of the World Christian Movement: Volume 1: Earliest Christianity To 1453|date=10 Jan 2002|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=9780567088666|page=202|edition=illustrated}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Solomon Alexander Nigosian|title=The Zoroastrian Faith: Tradition and Modern Research|date=1993|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=9780773511446|page=13|edition=reprint}}</ref>

[[File:伏見稲荷５.JPG|thumb|250px|Altar to [[Inari Ōkami]] at the [[Fushimi Inari-taisha|Fushimi Inari Shrine]] in [[Kyoto]]. [[Shinto]] is the ethnic religion of the [[Japanese people]].]]
In [[religious studies]], an '''ethnic religion''' (or '''indigenous religion''') is a [[religion]] associated with a particular [[ethnic group]]. Ethnic religions are often distinguished from [[universalizing religion|universal religions]] which claim to not be limited in ethnic or national scope, such as [[Christianity]] or [[Islam]] or [[Buddhism]] or [[Jainism]].<ref name="Hinnells">{{cite book |title=The Routledge companion to the study of religion |last=Hinnells |first=John R. |year=2005 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-33311-3 |pages=439–440 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IGspjXKxIf8C |accessdate=2009-09-17}}</ref> Ethnic religions are not only independent religions. Some localised denominations of global religions are practised solely by certain ethnic groups. For example, the [[Assyrian people|Assyrians]] have a unique denominational structure of Christianity known as the [[Assyrian Church of the East]].
== Terminology == A number of alternative terms have been used instead of "ethnic" or "indigenous" religions.
The term "primal religion" was coined by [[Andrew Walls]] in the University of Aberdeen in the 1970s to provide a focus on non-Western forms of religion as found in Africa, Asia, and Oceania.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Cox|first=James L.|last2=Sutcliffe|first2=Steven J.|date=1 March 2006|title=Religious studies in Scotland: A persistent tension with divinity|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.religion.2005.12.001|journal=Religion|volume=36|issue=1|pages=1–28|doi=10.1016/j.religion.2005.12.001}}</ref> Terms such as "primal religion," "primitive religion," and "tribal religion" have been contested by Walls' student, Jim Cox, who argues that such terms suggest an undeveloped religion which can be seen as a preparation for conversion to Christianity. Cox prefers to use the term "indigenous religion."<ref>{{Cite book|title=From Primitive to Indigenous: The Academic Study of Indigenous Religions|last=Cox|first=James L.|publisher=Ashgate|year=2007|isbn=978-0-754-65569-5|location=Aldershot|pages=9–31}}</ref>
Another term that is often used is "[[folk religion]]." While "ethnic religion" and "folk religion" have overlapping uses, the latter term implies "the appropriation of religious beliefs and practices at a popular level."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Concise Oxford Dictionary of World Religions|last=Bowker|first=John|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2000|isbn=978-0-191-72722-1|location=New York|pages=|chapter=Folk Religion}}</ref> The term "folk religion" can therefore be used to speak of [[Chinese folk religion|Chinese]] and [[Traditional African religion|African]] indigenous religions, but can also refer to popular expressions of more multi-national and institutionalized religions such as [[Folk Christianity]] or [[Folk Islam]].
== Usage == Ethnic religions are distinctive in their relationship with a particular [[ethnic group]] and often in the shaping of one's solidarity with an ethnic identity.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ethnicity and Religion: Intersections and Comparisons|last=|first=|publisher=Routledge|year=2011|isbn=978-1-138-88037-5|editor-last=Ruane|editor-first=Joseph B.|location=London|pages=|editor-last2=Todd|editor-first2=Jennifer}}</ref> Some ethnic religions include [[Hinduism]] of the [[Indian people|Indians]], [[Judaism]] of the [[Jews]], [[Chinese folk religion]] of the [[Han Chinese]], [[Shinto]] of the [[Japanese people|Japanese]], and [[Serer religion|A ƭat Roog]] of the [[Serer people|Serer]] of [[Senegal]], [[The Gambia]], and [[Mauritania]].<ref>[[Diedrich Hermann Westermann|Westermann, Diedrich]]; Smith, Edwin William; Forde, Cyril Daryll; [[International African Institute]]; [[International Institute of African Languages and Cultures]]; [[Project Muse]]; [[JSTOR]] (Organization), ''Africa: journal of the International African Institute, Volume 63'', pp 86-96, 270-1, [[Edinburgh University Press]] for the International African Institute (1993)</ref> [[Diaspora|Diasporic]] groups often maintain ethnic religions as a means of maintaining a distinct ethnic identity, such as [[Hinduism]] among [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|diasporic Indians]] in the [[Caribbean]], the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[United Kingdom]], [[France]], [[Netherlands]], [[Southern Africa|southern]] and [[East Africa|eastern Africa]], [[Mauritius]], [[Fiji]], and the [[Malay Peninsula]],<ref name="van der Veer">{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3773407 |last=van der Veer |first=Peter |author2=Steven Vertovec |date=April 1991 |title=Brahmanism Abroad: On Caribbean Hinduism as an Ethnic Religion |journal=Ethnology |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=149–166|jstor=3773407 }}</ref> or the role of [[Traditional African religion|African traditional religion]] and [[Afro-American religions]] among the [[African diaspora in the Americas]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thegrio.com/2011/10/19/african-religions-gain-following-among-black-christians/|title=Are blacks abandoning Christianity for African faiths?|last=Oduah|first=Chika|date=19 October 2011|website=theGrio|access-date=27 May 2016}}</ref>
Some ancient ethnic religions, such as those historically found in pre-modern Europe, have found new vitality in [[Modern Paganism|neopaganism]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Oxford Handbook of New Religious Movements|last=Lewis|first=James R.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=978-0-195-36964-9|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> Moreover, non-ethnic religions such as Christianity have been known to assume ethnic traits to an extent that they serve a role as an important ethnic identity marker,<ref name="Chong">{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3711911 |last=Chong |first=Kelly H. |year=1997 |title=What It Means to Be Christian: The Role of Religion in the Construction of Ethnic Identity and Boundary Among Second- Generation Korean Americans |journal=Sociology of Religion |volume=59 |issue=3 |pages=259–286|jstor=3711911 }}</ref> a notable example of this is the Serbian "Saint-Savianism" of the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]].<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=UxDRgBAOKLAC&pg=PA158&dq=serbian+nationalism+st+sava&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjrjovEvM7TAhUJ2mMKHeixDgIQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=serbian%20nationalism%20st%20sava&f=false</ref>
